A coin is tossed 1000 times and it landed heads 400 times. How confident we are whether the coin is fair ?

This is a pretty standard hypothesis testing problem. 

The sample size (n) is 1000 and we have observed heads 400 times meaning 
$\bar{p}$ = 0.4 and $\bar{q}$  = 0.6. 

The sample mean $\bar{x}$ is 400 and the sample standard deviation (s) is $\sqrt{1000*0.4*0.6}$ ~ 15.49

Now we do a test of proportions and our test statistic is ($\bar{p}$-${P}$)/$\sqrt{PQ/n}$

here P = Q = 0.5

Now the denominator $\sqrt{PQ/n}$ is the standard error of the sample proportion $\bar{p}$

The variance is scaled by square of n, so the variance of sample proportion is ${nPQ/n^{2}$ which is PQ/n and hence the standard error is  $\sqrt{PQ/n}$
